questions.text: The fluorescent in situ hybridization cannot be useful for detection of which of the following genetic defects?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point mutation

 

Point mutation: Point mutations involve a change in a single nucleotide base pair, which FISH cannot detect because it is designed to detect larger structural changes. For detecting point mutations, more sensitive techniques like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and specific variants such as single base primer extension assays are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes binding parts of the chromosome to detect and localize the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences. It is particularly useful for identifying genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations by visualizing the chromosomal location of the gene of interest.

 

Option A. Deletion: FISH can detect deletions by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the probe should bind.

 

Option C. Amplification: FISH can detect gene amplifications by showing multiple fluorescent signals in the region of interest.

 

Option D: Translocation: FISH can detect translocations by showing split signals in different parts of the chromosome or in different chromosomes, indicating that parts of the chromosome have been rearranged.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations but is effective for identifying larger genetic abnormalities such as deletions, amplifications, and translocations.

questions.text: As per WHO, the definition of blindness is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <3/60.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as having visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This means that a person who is blind cannot see at 3 meters what someone with normal vision can see at 60 meters. This definition is used globally to classify and diagnose blindness.

 

The same definition is used in the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India, ensuring consistency in how blindness is categorized both internationally and within the country.

 

Note –

 

  • In India, the current prevalence of blindness is 0.36%.
  • The most common cause of blindness is cataract (62%) >> refractive error (19.7%). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blindness, as defined by the WHO, is visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

choices.text: Intermediate filaments

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

 

The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.

 

i) Hepatocellular necrosis:

 

ii) Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline:

 

These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes. They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin). They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.

 

Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

iii) Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.

 

iv) Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a type of microfilament found in the cytoskeleton of cells, but it is not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option C. Microtubules: Microtubules are another component of the cytoskeleton, but they are not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option  D. Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a high-molecular-weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins such as integrins. It is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text: What is the minimum recommended thickness for a lead apron to protect the patient from radiation? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 0.25 mm

 

Lead aprons used for radiation protection require a minimum thickness of 0.25 mm to provide adequate shielding from radiation exposure. This minimum standard ensures basic protection for personnel working with radiation.

 

Explanation: 

 

While 0.25 mm represents the minimum acceptable thickness for lead aprons, most clinical facilities actually use thicker aprons of 0.5 mm for daily practice. The thickness directly correlates with the level of radiation attenuation provided by the apron.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. 0.50 mm - Though this is the most commonly used thickness in clinical settings, it exceeds the minimum requirement specified in radiation safety standards.
  • Option C. 0.75 mm - This thickness exceeds the minimum requirement and would create unnecessarily heavy aprons without proportional safety benefits.
  • Option D. 1.00 mm - This thickness is excessive for standard radiological procedures and would create ergonomic issues due to the weight.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum required lead apron thickness (0.25 mm) represents a balance between radiation protection and practical wearability, though healthcare facilities typically opt for greater protection with 0.5 mm thickness aprons.

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Factories Act? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories 

 

  • The Factories Act, established in 1948, specifically prohibits the employment of children under 14 years of age in factories. 
  • This legislation was enacted to ensure the protection of children from labor exploitation and to promote their welfare by restricting their employment in industrial environments.

 

FACTORIES ACT:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defense, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48hrs per week or less than 9hrs per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factories Act of 1948 critically mandates that children under the age of 14 must not be employed in factories, reflecting the law's strong stance on child labor and its emphasis on the health and safety of young individuals.

questions.text: Pressure on the artery proximal to an A-V fistula causes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in heart rate

 

Explanation:

 

In arteriovenous (A-V) fistulas, pressure on the artery proximal to the fistula reduces blood flow through the fistula. This causes a reduction in the size of the dilated veins, eliminates the thrill (palpable vibration), and stops the continuous bruit ("machinery murmur"). This occurs because proximal arterial compression blocks the arterial inflow to the fistula. However, heart rate is reduced, known as Branham’s bradycardia. This occurs as the hyperdynamic circulation due to the fistula reverts to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced size - When pressure is applied to the artery proximal to the fistula, the swelling of the arteriovenous fistula decreases as blood flow is reduced through the abnormal connection.

 

Option C. Reduced thrill - The thrill (palpable vibration) over an A-V fistula disappears when pressure is applied to the proximal artery because it interrupts the turbulent blood flow that creates the thrill.

 

Option D. Reduced pulse pressure - Compression of the feeding artery reduces blood flow through the fistula, eliminating the hemodynamic effects including the high-pulse pressure characteristic of A-V fistulas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Proximal arterial compression in A-V fistulas reduces local hemodynamic effects (size, thrill, bruit) by interrupting blood flow, while the heart rate reduces.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

This is the correct answer. DPPC is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and its deficiency in preterm infants is a key factor in the development of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. While it is a component of pulmonary surfactant, the primary deficiency in RDS is of DPPC.

 

L:S (Lecithin: Sphingomyelin) ratio > 2 is an indicator of fetal lung maturity at 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. It is found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

 

Disease related to Cardiolipins

 

  1. Barth Syndrome: Defect in cardiolipin remodelling
  2. Anti-Phospholipid Syndrome: Occurs due to Anticardiolipin antibodies formed in body. C/f are A thrombotic condition and Disease females has history of recurrent infection

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained above, DPPC is deficient in preterm babies with RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

questions.text: following intrauterine contraceptive devices does not need to be replaced even after 3-5 years of use? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CuT 380A

 

CuT 380A has the longest lifespan among the options provided. It contains 380 mm² of copper (314 mm² on the stem and 33 mm² on each arm) and can remain effective for up to 10 years before requiring replacement. This makes it the only option that doesn't need replacement within the 3-5 year timeframe mentioned in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CuT 200: This device has a much shorter lifespan of only 3 years. It contains 200 mm² of copper wire with 120 mg of copper and must be removed and replaced after this period.

 

Option B. CuT 375: This appears to refer to Multiload 375, which needs replacement after 5 years. This would require replacement at the upper limit of the timeframe mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Multiload Cu devices: These devices have shorter lifespans than CuT 380A. The Multiload Cu 250 requires replacement every 3 years, while the Multiload 375 requires replacement every 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CuT 380A is distinguished by its exceptionally long effective lifespan of 10 years, making it the most long-lasting copper intrauterine device available and an excellent choice for women seeking extended but reversible contraception without frequent replacements.

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and the following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simple primary repair

 

The scenario described suggests that the patient has a perforation of the small bowel, as indicated by the image showing a hole in the intestine. Abdominal wall rigidity is indicative of peritonitis, which results from the leakage of intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity due to a perforation. The provided images and description align with a small bowel perforation, likely in the jejunum or ileum.

 

In cases of small bowel perforations, particularly when the perforation is small, the standard management is a simple primary repair. This involves suturing the perforation directly, which is often sufficient to manage the defect without the need for more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis:
This is typically reserved for cases where the perforation is large, there are multiple perforations, or when the perforation is associated with a pathological condition like a stricture like in tubercular perforation. In the case described, a simple primary repair is usually sufficient.

 

Option B. Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch: This procedure, known as an omental patch or Graham's patch, is more commonly used for duodenal ulcers, not for small bowel perforations.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: This technique is not commonly used for repairing small bowel perforations. It is more suitable for specific types of perforations or fistulas but not typically indicated in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small bowel perforations, particularly in the jejunum or ileum, the primary approach is often a simple primary repair. This involves directly suturing the perforation and is usually effective for managing small perforations.

questions.text: Which of these is an indication for giving adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after resection and MRND? (An image of the flap reconstruction was shown).  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extranodal extension

 

Extranodal extension (ENE) refers to the spread of cancer beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding tissues. This feature has recently been added as a significant factor in the staging and management of head and neck cancers, including oral malignancies. ENE is associated with a poorer prognosis due to its aggressive nature and higher likelihood of recurrence. Therefore, it is a major criterion for adjuvant radiotherapy following surgery and MRND (modified radical neck dissection), as radiotherapy can help reduce the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple LN metastases: While having multiple involved lymph nodes is a sign of advanced disease, it alone does not necessarily mandate adjuvant radiotherapy unless combined with other factors, such as large nodal size (>3 cm) or other minor criteria.

Option C. T3 tumor: T3 tumors are generally considered advanced due to their size and extent. However, adjuvant radiotherapy is more strongly indicated when other adverse pathological features, such as ENE or involved surgical margins, are present.

 

Option D. Close margin (1.5-2 mm): Close surgical margins indicate that the tumor was resected near the boundary of normal tissue, increasing the risk of residual disease. However, a close margin alone is not as critical as an involved margin (<1 mm) and typically requires radiotherapy only if combined with other adverse features.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Extranodal extension is a key indication for adjuvant radiotherapy in oral malignancy after surgical resection and MRND due to its significant impact on prognosis and risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

choices.text: It is mostly in children
It can be associated with MEN 2A

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about a patient with a retroperitoneal mass, episodic hypertension, palpitations, and increased urinary VMA levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It can be associated with MEN 2A

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor that typically presents with episodic hypertension, palpitations, headaches, and elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) levels.

 

Pheochromocytomas are known to be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), which involves mutations in the RET gene. Patients with MEN 2A often present with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Remember – The genes associated with pheochromocytoma, includes the RET gene, P53 gene, VHL gene, and the succinate dehydrogenase B (SDHB) gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are more common in adults, and only about 10% of cases occur in children. Therefore, this statement is incorrect as the majority of cases are found in adults.

 

Option B. It is usually malignant: Pheochromocytomas are benign in about 90% of cases. Malignancy is seen in only about 10% of cases, so this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. It is mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are predominantly unilateral. Bilateral tumors are seen in only 10% of cases, often in familial syndromes such as MEN 2A. Hence, this statement is not accurate for the majority of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors associated with episodic hypertension and increased urinary VMA levels. They are commonly linked with MEN 2A syndrome, which involves RET gene mutations.

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • Laterally, the fibres of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca.
  • The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • It runs superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

 

 

The muscle has a broad attachment medially into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, situated behind the conjoint tendon. On the lateral side, its fibers spread out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliac without being attached to the iliac spines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. Instead, it is a thickened band of the iliopectineal fascia, which is an extension of the transversalis fascia. It runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament).

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract runs parallel to and posterior to the inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament). It forms the inferior border of the internal inguinal ring and provides a posterior boundary for the femoral canal.

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is not accurate. The iliopubic tract doesn't insert into the pubic tubercle. Instead, it runs laterally from the pubic tubercle, posterior to the inguinal ligament, and continues as the iliopectineal arch or fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the iliopubic tract moves laterally from the pubic tubercle, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle (often referred to as the iliac fascia or fascia iliaca). This provides a connection between the structures of the anterior abdominal wall and the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: The classification shown is for? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Pelvic organ prolapse


The classification shown in the image is the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system, which is used to classify pelvic organ prolapse.

 

Pelvic organ prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs, including the uterus, bladder, and rectum, into or outside of the vaginal canal. The POP-Q system is a standardized method that provides detailed measurements of the degree and location of prolapse using specific points and measurements.

 

The reference point in this classification is the hymen, and the system documents anterior wall descent, posterior wall descent, and other prolapse details through a 3x3 grid with six specific points (Aa, Ba, C, Ap, Bp, and D) and three measurements (genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length). This detailed system allows for accurate assessment and comparison of prolapse severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer:  is incorrect because cervical cancer staging does not use the POP-Q system. Instead, cervical cancer staging is typically done using FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) criteria, which focus on tumor size and spread rather than anatomical descent.

 

Option C. Vulvar cancer: is incorrect. Vulvar cancer staging is also not related to pelvic organ prolapse or the POP-Q classification. It typically involves examining tumor size and invasion depth.

 

Option D. Uterine anomalies: is incorrect because uterine anomalies refer to congenital abnormalities of uterine structure and do not involve prolapse quantification. These are usually diagnosed with imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, not classified with a system like POP-Q.

 

Educational Objective:


The POP-Q system is a specific and standardized classification method used to quantify and describe the extent of pelvic organ prolapse using detailed anatomical measurements. The hymen is the reference point for this classification.

questions.text: A patient presented with tingling and numbness in the legs, polyuria, and weight loss. He underwent a bone marrow aspirate (image as shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma with renal involvement

 

The bone marrow aspirate image shows numerous plasma cells with eccentric nuclei, which is a hallmark of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow.

 

Patients often present with symptoms such as polyuria, weight loss, and neuropathy due to the disease's impact on the kidneys and bones. The presence of more than 10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, renal involvement is common in multiple myeloma due to the deposition of monoclonal light chains, contributing to the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  SACD due to diabetes: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) in the context of diabetes would involve neuropathy, but it would not lead to the significant increase in plasma cells seen on the bone marrow aspirate. Bone marrow biopsy is not typically indicated in diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option B. SACD with B12 deficiency: This condition leads to neurological symptoms like tingling and numbness but usually presents with megaloblastic anemia rather than increased plasma cells. It does not explain the bone marrow findings or the systemic symptoms of polyuria and weight loss.

 

Option D. Metastasis: Metastatic disease can affect the bone marrow but would not typically present with a significant number of plasma cells with eccentric nuclei as seen in multiple myeloma. Additionally, the systemic symptoms and bone marrow findings align more closely with multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is identified by an increase in clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, accompanied by systemic symptoms such as renal involvement, neuropathy, and weight loss.

choices.text: Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Anitschkow cells is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Owl’s Eye Appearance on Transverse Section

 

Explanation: 

 

Anitschkow cells (also spelled Anitschkow) are a characteristic finding in rheumatic heart disease. These cells are activated macrophages (histiocytes) found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. This characteristic nuclear appearance gives them the name "caterpillar cells" due to their resemblance to a caterpillar on longitudinal section. The "owl's eye" appearance is not associated with Anitschkow cells but is typically seen in cytomegalovirus infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Cardiac Histocytes - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are plump activated macrophages (histiocytes) that appear in the myocardium as part of the inflammatory response in rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option B. Caterpillar Appearance on Longitudinal Section - This is correct. The centrally condensed chromatin appears as a slender, wavy ribbon, giving Anitschkow cells their characteristic "caterpillar" appearance.

 

Option D. Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease - This is correct. Anitschkow cells are found in Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease. These lesions represent a characteristic inflammatory response in the myocardium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anitschkow cells are distinctive activated macrophages with a "caterpillar" nuclear appearance (not "owl's eye") that are pathognomonic for rheumatic heart disease, typically found within Aschoff bodies in the myocardium.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is found to have shock and hypotension. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. X-ray is normal, and ECG shows no abnormalities. The SpO2 is 93%, and the blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 80/min. What type shock is most likely present? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neurogenic shock

 

Neurogenic shock results from disruption of sympathetic tone, often due to spinal cord injury or severe head injury. It is characterized by distributive shock with bradycardia and hypotension despite adequate intravascular volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic shock: Anaphylactic shock typically presents with symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, and hypotension following exposure to an allergen. It is characterized by distributive shock due to widespread vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.

 

Option B. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from acute blood loss, leading to decreased circulating volume and impaired tissue perfusion. It is characterized by hypovolemic shock, often with tachycardia, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output.

 

Option C. Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to cardiac pump failure, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. It is characterized by signs of low cardiac output, such as hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary congestion, and altered mental status.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a trauma patient with hypotension, negative eFAST, and no evidence of hemorrhage or cardiac dysfunction, neurogenic shock should be considered, especially in the context of spinal cord injury or severe head injury.

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th week

 

The neural tube closes by the end of the fourth week of gestation. Anencephaly occurs when the neural tube fails to close properly during this critical period.

 

Anencephaly is a serious birth defect in which a baby is born without parts of the brain and skull. It occurs when the upper part of the neural tube fails to close. The neural tube is the structure in a developing embryo that eventually becomes the baby's brain, spinal cord, and surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4th week of gestation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myoglobin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient presents with rhabdomyolysis following a high-voltage electrical injury, characterized by:

 

  • Muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine (myoglobinuria)
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels
  • Tender, swollen muscles

 

Myoglobin is released into circulation from damaged muscle cells and subsequently filtered by the kidneys, leading to myoglobinuria, which can cause acute kidney injury (AKI) due to tubular toxicity and obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RBCs: Would indicate hematuria, which is not the main feature of rhabdomyolysis

 

Option C. Creatine kinase: Although CK levels are elevated, CK is not excreted in urine

 

Option D. Bilirubin: Suggests liver dysfunction or hemolysis, not muscle breakdown

 

Educational Objective:

 

In rhabdomyolysis, myoglobin is released from damaged muscles, leading to myoglobinuria and a risk of acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A case of urinary bladder stone with a history of Proteus infection is likely to be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphate

 

Proteus infection in the urinary tract is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also known as triple phosphate stones. Struvite stones consist of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate. Proteus species produce the enzyme urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, increasing the urine pH and promoting the precipitation of phosphate, magnesium, and ammonium to form struvite stones.

 

These stones are often described as "infection stones" because they typically form in alkaline urine in the presence of a urinary tract infection caused by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalate: Oxalate stones are primarily composed of calcium oxalate and are not directly related to infections. They are often associated with dietary factors, hyperoxaluria, or conditions causing increased oxalate excretion.

 

Option C. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and are related to conditions that increase uric acid levels, such as gout or a high purine diet. They are not associated with Proteus infections or other urease-producing bacteria.

 

Option D. Cystine: Cystine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the excessive excretion of cystine in the urine. These stones are characterized by their hexagonal crystal shape but are not related to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary bladder stones associated with Proteus infection are most likely to be struvite (triple phosphate) stones, formed due to the alkalinizing effect of urease-producing bacteria on the urine.
